title: Introduction to BioTIMEr
text: loading BioTIMEr package, subset BioTIME data loaded together metadata. subset includes 12 studies marine, terrestrial freshwater time series across different taxonomic groups. whole BioTIME database accessible .
code: # Install and load the latest version of BioTIMEr library(BioTIMEr) # you can run the following commands to retrieve more information about the subsets. ?BTsubset_meta ?BTsubset_data # you can also see a full list of BioTIMEr functions and help pages by: ??BioTIMEr

title: Introduction to BioTIMEr
text: gridding() resampling() getAlphaMetrics() getBetaMetrics() getLinearRegressions () Visualise results. detailed run different steps, breaking tasks reasoning behind suggestions best practice analysing BioTIME data. use ‘pipe’ operator (|>) make code efficient streamlined, use ggplot2 library visualisations. libraries required BioTIMEr run , needed, installed time BioTIMEr installed.

what: Why bother with separating observations using a global grid?
title: Introduction to BioTIMEr
text: Typically, BioTIME study contains distinct samples collected consistent methodology given period time. However, spatial extent sample distribution among studies can vary substantially depending study taxon sampled (e.g. forest quadrants, bird transects, fish tows, etc.; can implemented within smaller larger areas). spatial extent varies among studies, advisable step grid studies large extents multiple sampling locations smaller equal-sized subsets. gridding() function designed perform task using global grid hexagonal cells derived dggridR (see vignette(‘dggridR’)). implementing gridding, large scales studies split multiple cell-level assemblages, small scale studies assigned single cell. Let’s apply gridding() subset BioTIME data see happens: Table 1 can see sample assigned different combination study ID grid cell (based latitude longitude) resulting unique identifier determines assemblage time series (assemblageID). assemblageID can now used study unit analysis biodiversity change based similar spatial extent . Let’s take look see many studies/cells/assemblages time series subset: Table 2 Figure 1 can see several studies partitioned, ’s observations already contained within single cell. default, function separates studies hexagonal cells ~96 km2 (res=12), resolution found appropriate working whole BioTIME database. Yet sometimes, particularly working subset BioTIME, may want explore alternative grid resolutions. function two options: can either directly define new resolution (see vignette(‘dggridR’)) allow function find best resolution based average study extent dataset. Let’s run alternative options examples: changed different res values? Figure 2 number cells study varies depending resolution chosen. can also map happens gridding data: Figure 3 can see higher resolution set higher number cells samples get assigned. thus risk resulting assemblages time series becoming small ecological meaning. good rule thumb never set res higher resolution get resByData = TRUE.
code: grid_samples <- gridding(   meta = BTsubset_meta,   btf = BTsubset_data,   res = 12,   resByData = FALSE )  # Get a look at the output grid_samples |> head() |> kable() check_res_1 <- grid_samples |>   summarise(     n_cell = n_distinct(cell),     n_aID = n_distinct(assemblageID),     res = "res12",     .by = c(STUDY_ID, StudyMethod)   )  check_res_1 |> head(10) |> kable() # How many samples were there in each study? ggplot(data = check_res_1) +   geom_bar(     mapping = aes(x = as.character(STUDY_ID), y = n_aID, fill = res),     stat = "identity"   ) +   scale_fill_discrete(type = c("#155f49")) +   xlab("StudyID") +   ylab("Number of assemblages in a study") +   theme_bw() +   theme(legend.position = "none") # define an alternative resolution of 14 (~10.7 km2 cells) grid_samples_14 <- gridding(   meta = BTsubset_meta,   btf = BTsubset_data,   res = 14,   resByData = FALSE )  # allow the spatial extent of the data to define the resolution grid_samples_auto <- gridding(   meta = BTsubset_meta,   btf = BTsubset_data,   res = 12,   resByData = TRUE ) # this option also returns a message with the automatically picked resolution: Resolution: 15, Area (km^2): 3.55473501726709, Spacing (km): 1.86210705534755, CLS (km): 2.12744663988395 check_res_2 <- grid_samples_14 |>   summarise(     n_cell = n_distinct(cell),     n_aID = n_distinct(assemblageID),     res = "res14",     .by = c(StudyMethod, STUDY_ID)   )  check_res_3 <- grid_samples_auto |>   summarise(     n_cell = n_distinct(cell),     n_aID = n_distinct(assemblageID),     res = "res15",     .by = c(StudyMethod, STUDY_ID)   )  checks <- rbind(check_res_1, check_res_2, check_res_3)  ggplot(data = checks) +   geom_bar(     mapping = aes(x = as.character(STUDY_ID), y = n_aID, fill = res),     stat = "identity",     position = "dodge"   ) +   scale_fill_discrete(type = c("#155f49", "#66c1d1", "#d9d956")) +   xlab("StudyID") +   ylab("Number of assemblages in a study") +   theme_bw() ## The following example is built on the demonstrations in ## https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/dggridR/vignettes/dggridR.html.  # First we build the ~96 km2 global grid dgg_12 <- dggridR::dgconstruct(res = 12)  # To simplify, we only map the grid cell boundaries for cells which # have observations. # NOTE: if you are working with the full BioTIME database, this step may take some time. grid_12 <- dggridR::dgcellstogrid(dgg_12, as.integer(grid_samples$cell))  # Now let's follow the same steps and build a ~10.7 km2 global grid: dgg_14 <- dggridR::dgconstruct(res = 14) grid_14 <- dggridR::dgcellstogrid(dgg_14, as.integer(grid_samples_14$cell))  # And we get some polygons for each country of the world, to create a background: countries <- ggplot2::map_data("world")  # Now you could map the whole world, but let's just zoom in the UK and have a look at # STUDY 466 (Marine Fish): map_uk_locations <- ggplot() +   geom_polygon(data = countries, aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group), fill = NA, color = "grey") +   geom_sf(data = grid_12, aes(), color = alpha("blue", 0.4)) +   coord_sf(xlim = c(-20, 10), ylim = c(50, 60)) +   geom_rect(aes(xmin = -11, xmax = -0.7, ymin = 57.2, ymax = 59), colour = "red", fill = NA) +   labs(x = NULL, y = NULL) +   theme_bw() + theme(text = element_text(size = 8))  zoom_in_map <- ggplot() +   geom_polygon(data = countries, aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group), fill = NA,                color = "grey") +   geom_sf(data = grid_12, aes(), color = alpha("blue", 0.4)) +   geom_sf(data = grid_14, aes(), color = alpha("red", 0.4)) +   coord_sf(xlim = c(-11, -0.7), ylim = c(57.2, 59)) +   theme_bw()  grid::grid.newpage() main <- grid::viewport(width = 1, height = 1, x = 0.5, y = 0.5)  # the main map inset <- grid::viewport(width = 0.4, height = 0.4, x = 0.82, y = 0.45)  # the inset in bottom left  # The resulting distribution of different size cells appears as follows: print(zoom_in_map, vp = main) print(map_uk_locations, vp = inset)

what: What happens if I change res?
title: Introduction to BioTIMEr
text: default, function separates studies hexagonal cells ~96 km2 (res=12), resolution found appropriate working whole BioTIME database. Yet sometimes, particularly working subset BioTIME, may want explore alternative grid resolutions. function two options: can either directly define new resolution (see vignette(‘dggridR’)) allow function find best resolution based average study extent dataset. Let’s run alternative options examples: changed different res values? Figure 2 number cells study varies depending resolution chosen. can also map happens gridding data: Figure 3 can see higher resolution set higher number cells samples get assigned. thus risk resulting assemblages time series becoming small ecological meaning. good rule thumb never set res higher resolution get resByData = TRUE.
code: # define an alternative resolution of 14 (~10.7 km2 cells) grid_samples_14 <- gridding(   meta = BTsubset_meta,   btf = BTsubset_data,   res = 14,   resByData = FALSE )  # allow the spatial extent of the data to define the resolution grid_samples_auto <- gridding(   meta = BTsubset_meta,   btf = BTsubset_data,   res = 12,   resByData = TRUE ) # this option also returns a message with the automatically picked resolution: Resolution: 15, Area (km^2): 3.55473501726709, Spacing (km): 1.86210705534755, CLS (km): 2.12744663988395 check_res_2 <- grid_samples_14 |>   summarise(     n_cell = n_distinct(cell),     n_aID = n_distinct(assemblageID),     res = "res14",     .by = c(StudyMethod, STUDY_ID)   )  check_res_3 <- grid_samples_auto |>   summarise(     n_cell = n_distinct(cell),     n_aID = n_distinct(assemblageID),     res = "res15",     .by = c(StudyMethod, STUDY_ID)   )  checks <- rbind(check_res_1, check_res_2, check_res_3)  ggplot(data = checks) +   geom_bar(     mapping = aes(x = as.character(STUDY_ID), y = n_aID, fill = res),     stat = "identity",     position = "dodge"   ) +   scale_fill_discrete(type = c("#155f49", "#66c1d1", "#d9d956")) +   xlab("StudyID") +   ylab("Number of assemblages in a study") +   theme_bw() ## The following example is built on the demonstrations in ## https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/dggridR/vignettes/dggridR.html.  # First we build the ~96 km2 global grid dgg_12 <- dggridR::dgconstruct(res = 12)  # To simplify, we only map the grid cell boundaries for cells which # have observations. # NOTE: if you are working with the full BioTIME database, this step may take some time. grid_12 <- dggridR::dgcellstogrid(dgg_12, as.integer(grid_samples$cell))  # Now let's follow the same steps and build a ~10.7 km2 global grid: dgg_14 <- dggridR::dgconstruct(res = 14) grid_14 <- dggridR::dgcellstogrid(dgg_14, as.integer(grid_samples_14$cell))  # And we get some polygons for each country of the world, to create a background: countries <- ggplot2::map_data("world")  # Now you could map the whole world, but let's just zoom in the UK and have a look at # STUDY 466 (Marine Fish): map_uk_locations <- ggplot() +   geom_polygon(data = countries, aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group), fill = NA, color = "grey") +   geom_sf(data = grid_12, aes(), color = alpha("blue", 0.4)) +   coord_sf(xlim = c(-20, 10), ylim = c(50, 60)) +   geom_rect(aes(xmin = -11, xmax = -0.7, ymin = 57.2, ymax = 59), colour = "red", fill = NA) +   labs(x = NULL, y = NULL) +   theme_bw() + theme(text = element_text(size = 8))  zoom_in_map <- ggplot() +   geom_polygon(data = countries, aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group), fill = NA,                color = "grey") +   geom_sf(data = grid_12, aes(), color = alpha("blue", 0.4)) +   geom_sf(data = grid_14, aes(), color = alpha("red", 0.4)) +   coord_sf(xlim = c(-11, -0.7), ylim = c(57.2, 59)) +   theme_bw()  grid::grid.newpage() main <- grid::viewport(width = 1, height = 1, x = 0.5, y = 0.5)  # the main map inset <- grid::viewport(width = 0.4, height = 0.4, x = 0.82, y = 0.45)  # the inset in bottom left  # The resulting distribution of different size cells appears as follows: print(zoom_in_map, vp = main) print(map_uk_locations, vp = inset)

title: Introduction to BioTIMEr
text: Now deal another common issue working time series data: fact number samples may vary time. evaluating changes time ’s important able quantify change independently number samples, .e. want able assess whether e.g. alpha diversity truly increased decreased time signal sampling artifact due uneven sampling effort – .e. resulting fewer samples different years periods time series compared. Probably common widely used approach prevent temporal variation sampling effort affecting diversity estimate apply sample-based rarefaction. (add link) great introduction . BioTIMEr provides resampling() function implements sample-based rarefaction, already adapted BioTIME data designed run smoothly previously gridded dataset done . function identifies minimum number samples across years time series uses minimum randomly resample year number. Let’s continue BioTIME example subset dataset: Table 3 Looking n_samples column can already see assemblages subset substantial differences sampling effort (.e. number samples) time. Thus, standardize sampling effort: function returns single long-form data frame containing total currency interest (.e. summed across samples) species year within assemblage time series. can specify currency field : Abundance, Biomass (BioTIME studies can include records either ). Note resampling() also tests removes NAs within selected currency field(s) implementing sample-based rarefaction. Thus, choose use currency fields, observations (conservative = FALSE) full sampling events (conservative = TRUE) Abundance Biomass recorded retained warning issued follows: Remember sample-based rarefaction involves randomly selecting specified number samples (.e. sampling events) year, number equal number samples year lowest sampling effort time series. sampling effort time equal relatively stable, probably need concern . However, many time series BioTIME (indeed biodiversity data) sampling effort can vary substantially, thus sample-based rarefaction process can lead different species diversity composition simply randomly selecting different samples. help exemplify point across, let’s pick one assemblage time series subset plot number samples recorded year: Figure 4 particular case, resampling()randomly select retain 3 samples year time series. can see plot, several years 20 samples ; run function second time ’s likely sample-based rarefaction process select different combination 3 samples (exception year 1927), may may differ species diversity composition. One option deal issue repeat random sampling process multiple times, effectively creating multiple alternative datasets time series (can used subsequent sensitivity analysis estimate variability diversity metrics originates random sample selection process): Table 4 Since sampling events within study retrieved consistent methodology observational effort, don’t expect see big differences picking sampling events others, however ’s still advisable check . example also highlights fact process standardising number samples per year within time series, lot data discarded. Additional steps, removing low sampling years, applying resampling() function may minimize effect. data now ready analysis! can stop go thing (world oyster!)…can follow next steps learn use BioTIMEr package estimate standard diversity metrics, well hints quantify visualize temporal biodiversity change given BioTIME data subset. Please note BioTIMEr designed interact BioTIME data, functions built using BioTIME variable names. However functions workflow describe can easily applied time series data long variable names modified accordingly .
code: # First, if you are not sure you need this step, # you can always check how many samples there are in every year of the different time series: check_samples <- grid_samples |>   summarise(     n_samples = n_distinct(SAMPLE_DESC),     n_species = n_distinct(Species),     .by = c(STUDY_ID, assemblageID, YEAR)   )  check_samples |> head(10) |> kable() # Let's apply resampling() then, using the data frame of the gridded data: grid_rare <- resampling(   x = grid_samples,   measure = "ABUNDANCE",   resamps = 1,   conservative = FALSE ) # Keep only observations with both abundance and biomass grid_rare_ab <- resampling(   x = grid_samples,   measure = c("ABUNDANCE", "BIOMASS"),   resamps = 1,   conservative = FALSE )  # Keep only sampling events where all observations within had both abundance and biomass to start with grid_rare_abT <- resampling(   x = grid_samples,   measure = c("ABUNDANCE", "BIOMASS"),   resamps = 1,   conservative = TRUE) # What is the number of samples in the year with the lowest sampling effort? ggplot(data = check_samples[check_samples$assemblageID == "18_335699",], aes(x = YEAR, y = n_samples)) +   geom_col(aes(x = YEAR, y = n_samples), fill = "red", alpha = 0.5) +   geom_segment(aes(x = 1926, y = min(n_samples) + 3,                    xend = 1927, yend = min(n_samples)),                arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.2, "cm"))) +   xlab("Year") +   ylab("Number of samples") +   theme_bw()  # In this case,the year 1927 had the lowest sampling effort, with 3 samples (arrow). # Let's implement the sample-based rarefaction by resampling the dataset 10 times. grid_rare_n10 <- resampling(   x = grid_samples,   measure = "ABUNDANCE",   resamps = 10,   conservative = FALSE )  # Note that you may want to resample many more times (e.g. at least 30-100+ times, but up to 199 # if e.g. working with the whole BioTIME data), depending on how many iterations you want a # subsequent bootstrap analysis to have. # This may also take some computation time, so if you are working with a big subset of BioTIME # is advisable to break it down in smaller subsets.  # Each resampling iteration will be identified as resamp = 1:n, in this case 1:10. # Now we can check if there are differences across the first 3 of these iterations:  check_resamps <- grid_rare_n10[grid_rare_n10$resamp < 4, ] |>   summarise(     n_obs = n(),     n_species = n_distinct(Species),     n_year = n_distinct(YEAR),     .by = c(STUDY_ID, assemblageID, resamp)   )  check_resamps |> head(10) |> kable()

what: How many resampling iterations should we implement?
title: Introduction to BioTIMEr
text: Remember sample-based rarefaction involves randomly selecting specified number samples (.e. sampling events) year, number equal number samples year lowest sampling effort time series. sampling effort time equal relatively stable, probably need concern . However, many time series BioTIME (indeed biodiversity data) sampling effort can vary substantially, thus sample-based rarefaction process can lead different species diversity composition simply randomly selecting different samples. help exemplify point across, let’s pick one assemblage time series subset plot number samples recorded year: Figure 4 particular case, resampling()randomly select retain 3 samples year time series. can see plot, several years 20 samples ; run function second time ’s likely sample-based rarefaction process select different combination 3 samples (exception year 1927), may may differ species diversity composition. One option deal issue repeat random sampling process multiple times, effectively creating multiple alternative datasets time series (can used subsequent sensitivity analysis estimate variability diversity metrics originates random sample selection process): Table 4 Since sampling events within study retrieved consistent methodology observational effort, don’t expect see big differences picking sampling events others, however ’s still advisable check . example also highlights fact process standardising number samples per year within time series, lot data discarded. Additional steps, removing low sampling years, applying resampling() function may minimize effect. data now ready analysis! can stop go thing (world oyster!)…can follow next steps learn use BioTIMEr package estimate standard diversity metrics, well hints quantify visualize temporal biodiversity change given BioTIME data subset. Please note BioTIMEr designed interact BioTIME data, functions built using BioTIME variable names. However functions workflow describe can easily applied time series data long variable names modified accordingly .
code: # What is the number of samples in the year with the lowest sampling effort? ggplot(data = check_samples[check_samples$assemblageID == "18_335699",], aes(x = YEAR, y = n_samples)) +   geom_col(aes(x = YEAR, y = n_samples), fill = "red", alpha = 0.5) +   geom_segment(aes(x = 1926, y = min(n_samples) + 3,                    xend = 1927, yend = min(n_samples)),                arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.2, "cm"))) +   xlab("Year") +   ylab("Number of samples") +   theme_bw()  # In this case,the year 1927 had the lowest sampling effort, with 3 samples (arrow). # Let's implement the sample-based rarefaction by resampling the dataset 10 times. grid_rare_n10 <- resampling(   x = grid_samples,   measure = "ABUNDANCE",   resamps = 10,   conservative = FALSE )  # Note that you may want to resample many more times (e.g. at least 30-100+ times, but up to 199 # if e.g. working with the whole BioTIME data), depending on how many iterations you want a # subsequent bootstrap analysis to have. # This may also take some computation time, so if you are working with a big subset of BioTIME # is advisable to break it down in smaller subsets.  # Each resampling iteration will be identified as resamp = 1:n, in this case 1:10. # Now we can check if there are differences across the first 3 of these iterations:  check_resamps <- grid_rare_n10[grid_rare_n10$resamp < 4, ] |>   summarise(     n_obs = n(),     n_species = n_distinct(Species),     n_year = n_distinct(YEAR),     .by = c(STUDY_ID, assemblageID, resamp)   )  check_resamps |> head(10) |> kable()

title: Introduction to BioTIMEr
text: Now following functions pretty straightforward. getAlphaMetrics() getBetaMetrics() estimate set common alpha beta diversity metrics year within time series BioTIME data. Let’s apply now processed BioTIME example dataset: many metrics measuring biodiversity community ecology. , focused commonly used metrics measuring temporal changes biodiversity. getAlphaMetrics() estimates nine alpha diversity metrics: Species richness (S), numerical abundance (N), maximum numerical abundance (maxN), Shannon index, Simpson index, inverse Simpson, McNaughton dominance, probability intraspecific encounter (PIE) exponential Shannon. getBetaMetrics() estimates three beta diversity metrics: Jaccard dissimilarity, Bray-Curtis dissimilarity Morisita-Horn dissimilarity, assuming first year time series baseline. Note N maxN metrics return numerical abundance measure=ABUNDANCE, biomass values measure=BIOMASS.
code: # Get alpha metrics estimates: alpha_metrics <- getAlphaMetrics(x = grid_rare, measure = "ABUNDANCE") # see also help("getAlphaMetrics") for more details on the metrics  # Have a quick look at the output alpha_metrics |> head(6) |> kable() # Get beta metrics estimates: beta_metrics <- getBetaMetrics(x = grid_rare, measure = "ABUNDANCE") #see also help("getBetaMetrics") for more details on the metrics  # Have a quick look at the output beta_metrics |> head(6) |> kable() # NOTE the functions used the rarefied data with only one resampling iteration

title: Introduction to BioTIMEr
text: Finally, looking measure biodiversity change using temporal data, common estimate temporal trends alpha diversity beta diversity fitting simple linear regression diversity estimates duration time series. getLinearRegressions() function implements linear models function year designed run smoothly output either getAlphaMetrics() getBetaMetrics() functions. Specifically, provides results simple linear regressions (slope, p-value, significance, intercept) using lm(), fit individually yearly diversity estimates metric within assemblage time series dataset. Table 5 Table 6 can change default P-value threshold statistical significance (.e. measure strength evidence H0). easy sorting, plotting interpretation, column called significance also provided, 1 indicates threshold met, .e. estimated slope significant specified p-value level. Also note biodiversity analysis may benefit additional transformations scaling data modelling (check nice tutorial subject ).
code: # Let's apply it then: alpha_slopes <- getLinearRegressions(   x = alpha_metrics,   pThreshold = 0.05 ) #for alpha metrics  # Have a quick look at the output alpha_slopes |> head(6) |> kable() # Let's apply it then: beta_slopes <- getLinearRegressions(   x = beta_metrics,   pThreshold = 0.05 ) #for beta metrics  # Have a quick look at the output beta_slopes |> head(6) |> kable()

title: Introduction to BioTIMEr
text: Now quantified change time, ready make plots! next section provides examples queries data visualization, ’s comprehensive exploration results, also vary depending research question. Right, let’s start overall summaries trends: Table 7 Let’s summary plots showing variation alpha diversity change: Figure 5 Now beta diversity change: Figure 6 ’s great! overall trends important, may also want evaluate patterns specific taxa climate, look sets trends (.e. significant non-significant) together. example, let’s say want look changes Shannon diversity two represented taxon example BioTIME dataset. Figure 7 might also want explore different trends given time series, allowing us visualise data trend line: Figure 8 can see results vary depending dataset metric change used. important remember biodiversity metrics just tool used measure changes, diverse abilities detect changes different biodiversity dimensions different scenarios e.g.thus provide different pieces complex puzzle may strongly affect interpretation biodiversity change.
code: # First, how many assemblages in our dataset show a moderate evidence (P < 0.05) of change in alpha diversity? alpha_slopes |>   filter(significance == 1) |>   # or use filter(pvalue<0.05)   summarise(n_sig = n_distinct(assemblageID), mean(slope), .by = metric) |>   kable() # We can see that only a few (<40) of the assemblage time series actually show a significant # trend of change over time, independently of the metric used. This indicates that in most # time series in the studies we analysed alpha diversity is not really changing through time. # Get a slope per assemblageID and metric alpha_slopes_simp <- alpha_slopes |>   filter(significance == 1) |> #select only the assemblages with significant trends   summarise(slope = unique(slope), .by = c(assemblageID, metric, pvalue))  # Calculate the mean slope and CIs stats_alpha <- alpha_slopes_simp |>   summarise(     mean_slope = mean(slope), #mean     ci_slope = qt(0.95, df = length(slope) - 1) *       (sd(slope, na.rm = TRUE) / sqrt(length(slope))),     .by = metric   ) #margin of error  # Let's put it all together ggplot(data = alpha_slopes_simp) +   geom_histogram(aes(x = slope, fill = metric), bins = 25) +   #geom_density(alpha=0.5)+ #in case you want a density plot instead   geom_vline(     aes(xintercept = 0),     linetype = 3,     colour = "grey",     linewidth = 0.5   ) + #add slope=0 line   geom_vline(     data = stats_alpha,     aes(xintercept = mean_slope),     linetype = 1,     linewidth = 0.5,     colour = "black"   ) + #mean   geom_vline(     data = stats_alpha,     aes(xintercept = mean_slope - ci_slope),     linetype = 2,     linewidth = 0.5,     colour = "black"   ) + #lower confidence interval   geom_vline(     data = stats_alpha,     aes(xintercept = mean_slope + ci_slope),     linetype = 2,     linewidth = 0.5,     colour = "black"   ) + #upper confidence interval   facet_wrap(~metric, scales = "free") +   scale_fill_biotime() + #using the customize BioTIME colour scale. See help("scale_color_biotime") for more options.   ggtitle("Alpha diversity change") +   theme_bw() +   theme(     legend.position = "none",     plot.title = element_text(size = 11, hjust = 0.5)   ) # Get a slope per assemblageID and metric beta_slopes_simp <- beta_slopes |>   filter(significance == 1) |> #select only the assemblages with significant trends   summarise(slope = unique(slope), .by = c(assemblageID, metric, pvalue))  # Calculate the mean slope and CIs stats_beta <- beta_slopes_simp |>   summarise(     mean_slope = mean(slope), #mean     ci_slope = qt(0.95, df = length(slope) - 1) *       (sd(slope, na.rm = TRUE) / sqrt(length(slope))),     .by = metric   ) #margin of error  # Let's put it all together ggplot(data = beta_slopes_simp) +   geom_histogram(aes(x = slope, fill = metric), bins = 25) +   #geom_density(alpha=0.5)+ #in case you want a density plot instead   geom_vline(     aes(xintercept = 0),     linetype = 3,     colour = "grey",     linewidth = 0.5   ) + #add slope=0 line   geom_vline(     data = stats_beta,     aes(xintercept = mean_slope),     linetype = 1,     linewidth = 0.5,     colour = "black"   ) + #mean   geom_vline(     data = stats_beta,     aes(xintercept = mean_slope - ci_slope),     linetype = 2,     linewidth = 0.5,     colour = "black"   ) + #lower confidence interval   geom_vline(     data = stats_beta,     aes(xintercept = mean_slope + ci_slope),     linetype = 2,     linewidth = 0.5,     colour = "black"   ) + #upper confidence interval   facet_wrap(~metric, scales = "free") +   scale_fill_biotime() + #using the customize BioTIME colour scale. See help("scale_color_biotime") for more options.   ggtitle("Beta diversity change") +   theme_bw() +   theme(     legend.position = "none",     plot.title = element_text(size = 11, hjust = 0.5)   ) # Hint: If you wish to plot all metrics together, simply merge you alpha_slopes and # beta_slopes dataframes beforehand. # First, we need to check the meta file and retrieve the information for the studies of interest #head(BTsubset_meta) meta <- select(BTsubset_meta, STUDY_ID, TAXA, REALM, CLIMATE)  # Get a slope per assemblageID and metric alpha_slopes_simp <- alpha_slopes |>   summarise(     slope = unique(slope),     .by = c(assemblageID, metric, pvalue, significance)   )  # Get back the Study ID by separating our assemblageID column into multiple other columns. alpha_slopes_simp <- alpha_slopes_simp |>   separate_wider_delim(     cols = assemblageID,     names = c("STUDY_ID", "cell"),     delim = "_",     cols_remove = FALSE   ) |>   as.data.frame()  # Merge it all alpha_slopes_meta <- merge(alpha_slopes_simp, meta, by = "STUDY_ID")  # Select relevant data for plotting alpha_slopes_set1 <- subset(   alpha_slopes_meta,   alpha_slopes_meta$metric == "Shannon" &     (alpha_slopes_meta$TAXA == "Fish" | alpha_slopes_meta$TAXA == "Birds") )  # Let's put it all together ggplot(data = alpha_slopes_set1, aes(x = slope, fill = TAXA)) +   geom_histogram(fill = "grey", bins = 25) + #all assemblages   geom_histogram(     data = alpha_slopes_set1[alpha_slopes_set1$significance == 1, ],     bins = 25   ) + #only significant change assemblages   geom_vline(     aes(xintercept = 0),     linetype = 3,     colour = "black",     linewidth = 0.5   ) + #add slope=0 line   facet_wrap(~TAXA, scales = "free") +   scale_fill_biotime() +   ggtitle("Shannon-Weiner Species Diversity Index") +   theme_bw() +   theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 11, hjust = 0.5)) # Now we see the full distribution of slopes of change for the Shannon index for the birds # and fish time series in our subset: all slopes are shown in grey, while in color we show # the subset of assemblages for which evidence (P < 0.05) of change was detected. # Let's go back to the data frame with the yearly values and select our relevant data for plotting alpha_metrics_set <- subset(alpha_metrics, assemblageID == "18_335699")  # Transform data alpha_metrics_set_long <- pivot_longer(alpha_metrics_set,                                    cols = c("S", "N", "maxN", "Shannon", "expShannon",                                    "Simpson", "invSimpson", "PIE", "DomMc"),                                    names_to = "metric",                                    names_transform = as.factor)  # Get assemblage ID slope of change alpha_slopes_set2 <- subset(alpha_slopes, assemblageID == "18_335699")  # Get assemblage ID name_assemblage <- unique(alpha_slopes_set2$assemblageID)  # Merge info alpha_metr_slop<- left_join(   x = alpha_slopes_set2,   y = alpha_metrics_set_long,   by = join_by(assemblageID, metric))  # Let's put it all together ggplot(data = alpha_metr_slop, aes(x = YEAR, y = value)) +     geom_point(colour = "#155f49", size = 1) +   #plot the yearly estimates     stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, linetype = 2, colour = "grey") + #draw all regression line     stat_smooth(data = subset(alpha_metr_slop, alpha_metr_slop$significance == 1),                 aes(x = YEAR, y = value), method = "lm", se = FALSE,                 linetype = 2, colour = "#155f49") + #color only trends that are significant     facet_wrap(~metric, scales = "free") +     scale_fill_biotime() +     ggtitle(paste("Assemblage", name_assemblage)) + ylab("Diversity") +     theme_bw() +     theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 11, hjust = 0.5))

title: Introduction to BioTIMEr
text: R package developed BioTIME team. functions documentation developed predominantly Alban Sagouis, Faye Moyes Inês S. Martins. optimal use, package operate manner described . Feedback appreciated, particularly come across errors like suggest changes. Updates made sporadically.

what: Tools to Use and Explore the BioTIME Database
title: Tools to Use and Explore the BioTIME Database
text: BioTIMEr R package gives functions work BioTIME communities provides subset BioTIME database. BioTIME (Global database assemblage time series quantifying understanding biodiversity change) international network open access database, free anyone, anywhere world use education, research, conservation. complete description database, please refer open access publication entitled BioTIME 2.0: Expanding Improving Database Biodiversity Time Series.

title: Tools to Use and Explore the BioTIME Database
code: install.packages("BioTIMEr") # CRAN version remotes::github_install("bioTIMEHub/BioTIMEr", ref = "dev") # dev version

title: Tools to Use and Explore the BioTIME Database
text: BioTIME users interested standardising extent datasets. using data subset included inside package. likely following step rarefy communities common sampling effort.
code: library(BioTIMEr) gridding(BTsubset_meta, BTsubset_data) gridding(BTsubset_meta, BTsubset_data) |>    resampling("ABUNDANCE")

title: BioTIME subset — BTsubset_data
text: subset data BioTIME temporal surveys.

title: BioTIME subset — BTsubset_data
code: BTsubset_data

title: BioTIME subset — BTsubset_data
text: ## `BTsubset_data` data frame 81,084 rows 17 columns: ID_ALL_RAW_DATA Unique BioTIME identifier record ABUNDANCE Double representing abundance record (see metadata details ABUNDANCE_TYPE BIOMASS Double representing biomass record (see metadata details BIOMASS_TYPE ID_SPECIES Unique identifier linking species table SAMPLE_DESC Concatenation variables comprising unique sampling event LATITUDE Latitude record LONGITUDE Longitude record DEPTH Depth elevation record available DAY Numerical day record MONTH Numerical value month record, .e. January=1 YEAR Year record STUDY_ID BioTIME study unique identifier newID Validated species identifier key valid_name Highest taxonomic resolution individual, preferred genus species resolution Level resolution, .e. 'species' represented genus species taxon Higher level taxonomic grouping, .e. Fish

title: BioTIME subset — BTsubset_data
text: <https://biotime.st-andrews.ac.uk/download.php>

title: BioTIME subset metadata — BTsubset_meta
text: subset metadata BioTIME

title: BioTIME subset metadata — BTsubset_meta
code: BTsubset_meta

title: BioTIME subset metadata — BTsubset_meta
text: ## `BTsubset_meta` data frame 12 rows 25 columns: STUDY_ID BioTIME study unique identifier REALM Realm study location, .e. Marine CLIMATE Climate study location, .e. Temperate HABITAT Habitat study location, .e. Rivers PROTECTED_AREA Binary variable indicating study within protected area BIOME_MAP Biome study location (taken WWF biomes, .e. Temperate broadleaf mixed forests TAXA High level taxonomic identity study species, .e. Fish ORGANISMS detailed information taxonomy, .e. woody plants TITLE Title study identified original source AB_BIO , B AB designate abundance , biomass DATA_POINTS Number unique data points study, e.g. 10 data points spanning 15 years = 10 START_YEAR First year study END_YEAR Last year study CENT_LAT Central latitude taken convex hull around study coordinates CENT_LONG Central longitude taken convex hull around study coordinates NUMBER_OF_SPECIES Number distinct species study NUMBER_OF_SAMPLES Number distinct samples study NUMBER_LAT_LONG Number distinct geographic coordinates study TOTAL Total number records study GRAIN_SIZE_TEXT Grain size described text, .e. size forest plots AREA_SQ_KM Total area study km2 DATE_STUDY_ADDED Date study added database ABUNDANCE_TYPE Type abundance, .e. count BIOMASS_TYPE Type biomass, .e. weight SAMPLE_DESC Concatenation descriptors comprising unique sampling event

title: BioTIME subset metadata — BTsubset_meta
text: <https://biotime.st-andrews.ac.uk/download.php>

title: Alpha — getAlpha
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # 1 site, 1 year in long format, ordered by ABUNDANCE or BIOMASS x <- data.frame(species = letters[1:6], x = 6:1) getAlpha(x$x) } # }

title: Alpha diversity metrics — getAlphaMetrics
text: Calculates set standard alpha diversity metrics

title: Alpha diversity metrics — getAlphaMetrics
code: getAlphaMetrics(x, measure)

title: Alpha diversity metrics — getAlphaMetrics
text: x (data.frame) BioTIME data format output resampling function. measure (character) chosen currency defined single column name.

title: Alpha diversity metrics — getAlphaMetrics
text: Returns data.frame results species richness (S), numerical  abundance (N), maximum numerical abundance (maxN), Shannon Index (Shannon),  Exponential Shannon (expShannon), Simpson's Index (Simpson), Inverse Simpson  (InvSimpson), Probability intraspecific encounter (PIE) McNaughton's  Dominance (DomMc) year assemblageID.

title: Alpha diversity metrics — getAlphaMetrics
text: function getAlphaMetrics computes nine alpha diversity metrics given community data frame, measure character input specifying abundance biomass field used calculations. row data frame data, getAlphaMetrics calculates following metrics: - Species richness (S) total number species year currency > 0. - Numerical abundance (N) total currency (sum) year (either total abundance total biomass). - Maximum Numerical abundance (maxN) highest currency value reported year. - Shannon Shannon–Weaver index calculated \(\sum_{}p_{}log_{b}p_{}\), \(p_{}\) proportional abundance species b base logarithm (natural logarithms), exponential Shannon given exp(Shannon). - Simpson's index calculated \(1-sum(p_{}^{2})\), Inverse Simpson \(1/sum(p_{}^{2})\). - McNaughton's Dominance calculated sum pi two abundant species. - Probability intraspecific encounter PIE calculated \(\left(\frac{N}{N-1}\right)\left(1-\sum_{=1}^{S}\pi_{}^{2}\right)\). Note input data frame needs format output  gridding function /resampling functions,  includes keeping default BioTIME data column names. columns  found error issued computations halted.

title: Alpha diversity metrics — getAlphaMetrics
code: # Mean and sd values of the metrics for several resamplings   gridding(BTsubset_meta, BTsubset_data) |>     resampling(measure = "BIOMASS", resamps = 2) |>     getAlphaMetrics(measure = "BIOMASS") |>     dplyr::summarise(        dplyr::across(           .cols = !resamp,           .fns = c(mean = mean, sd = sd)),        .by = c(assemblageID, YEAR)) |>     tidyr::pivot_longer(        col = dplyr::contains("_"),        names_to = c("metric", "stat"),        names_sep = "_",        names_transform = as.factor) |>     tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = stat) |>     head(10) #> OK: all SL studies have 1 grid cell #> Warning: NA values found and removed. #> Only a subset of `x` is used. #> # A tibble: 10 × 5 #>    assemblageID  YEAR metric       mean    sd #>    <chr>        <int> <fct>       <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 211_504467    1984 S          11         0 #>  2 211_504467    1984 N          11.8       0 #>  3 211_504467    1984 maxN        2.9       0 #>  4 211_504467    1984 Shannon     2.02      0 #>  5 211_504467    1984 Simpson     0.850     0 #>  6 211_504467    1984 invSimpson  6.66      0 #>  7 211_504467    1984 PIE         0.929     0 #>  8 211_504467    1984 DomMc       0.409     0 #>  9 211_504467    1984 expShannon  7.55      0 #> 10 211_504467    1985 S           5         0

title: Beta diversity metrics — getBetaMetrics
text: Returns data.frame results Jaccard dissimilarity (JaccardDiss), Morisita-Horn dissimilarity (MorisitaHornDiss), Bray-Curtis dissimilarity (BrayCurtsDiss) year assemblageID.

title: Beta diversity metrics — getBetaMetrics
text: function getBetaMetrics computes three beta diversity metrics given community data frame, measure character input specifying abundance biomass field used calculations. getBetaMetrics calls vegdist function calculates row following metrics: Jaccard dissimilarity (method = "jaccard"), Morisita-Horn dissimilarity (method = "horn") Bray-Curtis dissimilarity (method = "bray"). , dissimilarity metrics calculated baseline year assemblage time series .e. first year time series. Note input data frame needs format output  gridding /resampling functions, includes keeping default BioTIME data column names. columns found error  issued computations halted.

title: Beta diversity metrics — getBetaMetrics
code: gridding(BTsubset_meta, BTsubset_data) |>   resampling(measure = "BIOMASS", verbose = FALSE, resamps = 2) |>   getBetaMetrics(measure = "BIOMASS") |>   head() #> OK: all SL studies have 1 grid cell #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   resamp assemblageID  YEAR JaccardDiss MorisitaHornDiss BrayCurtisDiss #>    <int> <chr>        <int>       <dbl>            <dbl>          <dbl> #> 1      1 211_504467    1984       0.593           0.384           0.500 #> 2      1 211_504467    1985      NA              NA              NA     #> 3      1 211_516855    1982       0.741           0.107           0.372 #> 4      1 211_516855    1983       0.726           0.0925          0.941 #> 5      1 211_516855    1984       0.700           0.0258          0.794 #> 6      1 211_516855    1985       0.661           0.159           0.926

title: Get Linear Regressions BioTIME — getLinearRegressions

title: Get Linear Regressions BioTIME — getLinearRegressions
code: x <- data.frame(     resamp = 1L,     YEAR = rep(rep(2010:2015, each = 4), times = 4),     Species = c(replicate(n = 8L * 6L, sample(letters[1L:10L], 4L, replace = FALSE))),     ABUNDANCE = rpois(24 * 8, 10),     assemblageID = rep(LETTERS[1L:8L], each = 24)   )   alpham <- getAlphaMetrics(x, "ABUNDANCE")   getLinearRegressions(x = alpham, pThreshold = 0.01) |> head(10) #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #>    assemblageID     metric         slope     pvalue significance   intercept #> 1             A     resamp -7.769943e-17 0.15830242            0    1.000000 #> 2             A          S -3.107977e-16 0.15830242            0    4.000000 #> 3             A          N -1.285714e+00 0.11140387            0 2628.666667 #> 4             A       maxN -8.571429e-01 0.02754026            0 1738.333333 #> 5             A    Shannon  7.882316e-03 0.02894903            0  -14.504070 #> 6             A    Simpson  3.794763e-03 0.02419558            0   -6.900193 #> 7             A invSimpson  5.412274e-02 0.02416741            0 -105.120103 #> 8             A        PIE  4.459757e-03 0.01247305            0   -8.220043 #> 9             A      DomMc -1.699026e-02 0.01814172            0   34.786969 #> 10            A expShannon  3.056364e-02 0.02888373            0  -57.616190    betam <- getBetaMetrics(x = x, "ABUNDANCE")   getLinearRegressions(x = betam) |> head(10) #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #> Warning: essentially perfect fit: summary may be unreliable #>    assemblageID           metric         slope    pvalue significance intercept #> 1             A           resamp -7.769943e-17 0.1583024            0   1.00000 #> 2             A      JaccardDiss  5.442177e-03 0.8540797            0 -10.19048 #> 3             A MorisitaHornDiss  2.926540e-02 0.5241308            0 -58.21054 #> 4             A   BrayCurtisDiss  2.744839e-02 0.4200657            0 -54.54639 #> 5             B           resamp -7.769943e-17 0.1583024            0   1.00000 #> 6             B      JaccardDiss -5.551020e-02 0.2250488            0 112.32381 #> 7             B MorisitaHornDiss -4.206310e-02 0.2035292            0  85.06557 #> 8             B   BrayCurtisDiss -4.220078e-02 0.2102584            0  85.46654 #> 9             C           resamp -7.769943e-17 0.1583024            0   1.00000 #> 10            C      JaccardDiss  2.258503e-02 0.7028507            0 -44.71111

title: gridding BioTIME data — gridding
text: grids BioTIME data discrete global grid based    location samples (latitude/longitude).

title: gridding BioTIME data — gridding
code: gridding(meta, btf, res = 12, resByData = FALSE, verbose = TRUE)

title: gridding BioTIME data — gridding
text: meta (data.frame, tibble data.table) BioTIME metadata. btf (data.frame, tibble data.table) BioTIME data. res (integer) cell resolution. Must range [0,30]. Larger values represent finer resolutions. Default: 12 (~96 sq km). Passed dgconstruct. resByData (logical) FALSE default. TRUE, function dg_closest_res_to_area called adapt res  data extent. new res value used even value  provided byt user. verbose TRUE, warning shown one-year-long time series found btf excluded.

title: gridding BioTIME data — gridding
text: Returns 'data.frame', selected columns btf meta data frames, extra integer column called 'cell' two character columns called 'StudyMethod' 'assemblageID' (concatenation STUDY_ID cell).

title: gridding BioTIME data — gridding
text: BioTIME study contains distinct samples collected consistent methodology time, unique coordinates date. samples can fixed plots (.e. SL 'single-location' studies measures taken set specific georeferenced sites given time) wide-ranging surveys, transects, tows, (.e. ML 'multi-location' studies measures taken multiple sampling locations large extents may may align year year, see runResampling. gridding function designed deal issue varying spatial extent studies using global grid hexagonal cells derived dgconstruct assigning individual samples cells across grid based latitude longitude. Specifically, sample assigned different combination study ID grid cell resulting unique identifier assemblage time series within cell (assemblageID). allows integrity study sample maintained, large extent studies split local time series grid cell level. default meta represents long form data frame containing data information BioTIME studies btf data frame containing long form data main BioTIME query (see Example). res defines global grid cell resolution, thus determining size cells (see vignette("dggridR")). res = 12 found appropriate value working whole BioTIME database(corresponding ~96 km2 cell area), user can define grid resolution (e.g. res = 14, resbyData = TRUE allow function find best res based average study extent.

title: gridding BioTIME data — gridding
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   gridded_data <- gridding(meta = BTsubset_meta, btf = BTsubset_data)   gridded_data <- gridding(meta = dplyr::as_tibble(BTsubset_meta),                            btf = dplyr::as_tibble(BTsubset_data))   gridded_data <- gridding(meta = data.table::as.data.table(BTsubset_meta),                            btf = data.table::as.data.table(BTsubset_data)) } # }

Larger values represent finer resolutions. Default: 12 (~96 sq km). Passed dgconstruct. resByData (logical) FALSE default. TRUE, function dg_closest_res_to_area called adapt res  data extent. new res value used even value  provided byt user. verbose TRUE, warning shown one-year-long time series found btf excluded.

title: Plot slopes BioTIME — plotSlopes
code: plotSlopes(   x,   metric,   cols,   taxa = c("Amphibians & reptiles", "Birds", "Chromista", "Fish", "Fungi", "Mammals",     "Plants"),   method = c("metric", "taxa", "ind"),   assemblageID,   divType = c("alpha", "beta") )

title: Plot slopes BioTIME — plotSlopes
text: x data.frame columns slopes, metric, taxa, assemblageID metric divtype alpha, metric must one "S", "N", "maxN", "Shannon", "Simpson", "invSimpson", "PIE", "DomMc" "expShannon". divtype beta, metric must one "JaccardDiss", "MorisitaHornDiss" "BrayCurtisDiss". cols Name column x colouring groups based . taxa Necessary method = "taxa", one : "Amphibians & reptiles", "Birds", "Chromista", "Fish", "Fungi", "Mammals", "Plants" method Character can one "metric", "taxa", "ind" assemblageID Parameter description divType "alpha" "beta"

title: Plot slopes BioTIME — plotSlopes
text: plot

what: Rarefy BioTIME data to an equal number of samples per year — resampling
title: Rarefy BioTIME data to an equal number of samples per year — resampling
text: Takes output gridding applies sample-based rarefaction standardise number samples per year within cell-level time series (.e. assemblageID).

title: Rarefy BioTIME data to an equal number of samples per year — resampling
code: resampling(   x,   measure,   resamps = 1L,   conservative = FALSE,   summarise = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Rarefy BioTIME data to an equal number of samples per year — resampling
text: x (data.frame) BioTIME gridded data resampled (format output gridding function). measure (character) currency retained sample-based rarefaction. Can either defined single column name vector two column names. resamps (integer) number repetitions. Default 1. conservative (logical). FALSE default. TRUE, whenever NA found measure field(s), whole sample removed instead missing observations . summarise (logical). TRUE default. FALSE, function returns abundance /biomass summed SAMPLE_DESC level git pull(.e., per sample), rather per species per year. verbose TRUE, warning shown one-year-long time series found btf excluded.

title: Rarefy BioTIME data to an equal number of samples per year — resampling
text: Returns single long form data.frame containing total currency currencies interest (sum) species year within rarefied time series (.e. assemblageID). extra integer column called resamp indicates specific iteration.

title: Rarefy BioTIME data to an equal number of samples per year — resampling
text: Sample-based rarefaction prevents temporal variation sampling effort affecting diversity estimates (see Gotelli N.J., Colwell R.K. 2001 Quantifying biodiversity: procedures pitfalls measurement comparison species richness. Ecology Letters 4(4), 379-391) selecting equal number samples across years time series. resampling counts number unique samples taken year (sampling effort), identifies minimum number samples across years, uses minimum randomly resample year number. Thus, standardising sampling effort years, standard biodiversity metrics can calculated based equal number samples (e.g. using getAlphaMetrics, getAlphaMetrics).  measure character input specifying chosen currency used sample-based rarefaction. can single column name vector two column names - e.g. BioTIME, measure="ABUNDANCE", measure="BIOMASS" measure = c("ABUNDANCE", "BIOMASS"). default, observations NA within currency field(s) removed. can choose remove full sample observations present setting conservative TRUE. resamps can used define multiple iterations, effectively creating multiple alternative datasets iteration different samples randomly selected years number samples > minimum. Note function always returns single data frame, .e. resamps > 1, returned data frame result individual data frames concatenated together, one iteration identified numerical unique identifier 1:resamps.

title: Rarefy BioTIME data to an equal number of samples per year — resampling
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   set.seed(42)   x <- gridding(BTsubset_meta, BTsubset_data)   resampling(x, measure = "BIOMASS", summarise = TRUE)   resampling(x, measure = "ABUNDANCE", verbose = FALSE)   resampling(x, measure = c("ABUNDANCE","BIOMASS"))   # Without summarising the species abundances are summed at the SAMPLE_DESC level   resampling(x, measure = "BIOMASS", summarise = FALSE, conservative = FALSE) } # }

title: ggplot2 theme for BioTIME plots — themeBioTIME

title: ggplot2 theme for BioTIME plots — themeBioTIME
text: legend.position default position legends ("none", "left", "right", "bottom", "top", "inside") font.size Size axes labels, legend text title (+1), title (+2). axis.colour Colour name axes, ticks axis labels. strip.background Colour name. Passed theme fill colour strip.background element. axis.color US spelling axis.colour. fontSize Deprecated Favour font.size colx Deprecated favour axis.colour. coly Deprecated favour strip.background. lp Deprecated favour legend.position.

title: BioTIMEr 0.3.0 - 29.11.2025
text: CRAN release: 2025-11-28

title: BioTIMEr 0.3.0 - 29.11.2025
text: package now uses data.table background major speed memory usage improvements. Resampling whole BioTIME database used take > 1 hour now takes < 1 minute. methods: gridding resampling functions now handle data.frame, data.table tibble objects dedicated functions. getAlphaMetrics getBetaMetrics faster use 100x less memory.

title: BioTIMEr 0.3.0 - 29.11.2025
text: resampling function: new argument summarise, TRUE default keeps previous behaviour. TRUE, abundance /biomass summed per rarefyID FALSE abundance /biomass summed per rarefyID/SAMPLE_DESC gives columns. getAlphaMetrics getBetaMetrics functions: data.frames containing several resamplings accepted provided data contain several resamplings, metrics computed per resampling, per assemblageID, per year. getLinearRegressions function: removed divType argument. function now reads class objects produced getAlphaMetrics getBetaMetrics computes expected metrics.

title: BioTIMEr 0.3.0 - 29.11.2025
text: themeBioTIME function: argument lp soft deprecated favour legend.position argument fontSize soft deprecated favour font.size argument colx soft deprecated favour axis.colour argument coly soft deprecated favour strip.background order arguments change.
